Like that's a, well, if black lives matter, then I'd say hypocrisy to say only one ethnic group. So both sides sling mud, that's called, about hypocrisy all the time. Because Christians, we would say, yeah, well, I mean, welcome to humans. Right? Yes. Sometimes. Are we saying that that, like, is that a correct way of saying, like when we say, well, that's hypocritical. Is that actually hypocritical? It might be. Okay. It may be emphasis, like, like with the black lives matter slogan. I'm not supporting the movement or the website or anything, but the slogan does not say that all lives don't matter. It's just saying we're drawing attention to the fact that sometimes it doesn't seem like black lives matter the way they should. And so we're not saying that other lives don't matter. We're just, no, we're just trying to talk about this right now. The same thing would be true about, you know, if I get up and say, if somebody gets up and says they're pro-life, you know, we need to protect unborn children. Well, what about these other kids? Yeah, absolutely. Those two, we're just drawing attention right now to, that's not hypocrisy to say we're trying to care for one population. That doesn't mean we don't care about the other. We're just bringing attention to this one. Oh, you only care about foster kids, not adopted kids. No, we just don't have, we can't do both. We can't do everything all the time, right? So that's not, I don't think that's hypocrisy. It is hypocrisy though, if you actually don't care about, so if you say, here's one of my favorites, two populations that call each other hypocrites kind of constantly is people who are pro-capital punishment, but anti-abortion and vice versa. And so what is the, how do you deal with, so you believe in the sanctity of human life, but you also believe the government should be able to take away human life, that seems hypocritical to some. Or you say you want to protect children, but you don't want to get rid of guns. That seems hypocritical because a lot of children die from gun violence. So what I love is when people who just assume that, oh, you must be a hypocrite because, but the other side will say the same, you say you want to protect children, but you won't arm guards at the school. You're a hypocrite. There's always two sides to this. And so sometimes when you can get people together and realize, and the gun control one is one I've seen happen when you sit down and somebody says, oh, you're trying to protect kids just like I am. You just think there's a better way to do it. So this isn't a matter of you hate kids and I love kids, which would be hypocrisy. It is, no, no, we both love kids. We're both trying to take care of them. We just disagree on the best way to do it. Well, that's not hypocrisy. That's just disagreement. Like the humility to admit where you do agree. Yeah. Yeah. And so anyway, we would hope for that whenever possible, that that's part of the conversation. And I think it's even more damaging when you associate it with Christianity, when it's Christians having those conversations of saying, I'm painting hypocrisy on you because you don't see eye to eye politically on how to handle this situation with me. It's like you're not serving the Lord because you politically think this is the way to handle the situation. Yeah. Yeah. There's a an area of hypocrisy that I got called out on that I really appreciate it. And it changed my life, which was the claim that I wanted to change our nation, turn things around for our nation, you know, have a Christian great awakening, all this type of thing. And someone said, well, you realize if we fostered and adopted all the kids out of the foster and adoption system, we would then probably have the influence over the rest of our nation. We could shut down prisons. We could, you know, we could do make all kinds of massive changes. And it's not like we don't know how to do that. This is you don't need to wait and figure out how to do this. You can do this now. You can have a role in this. Well, when I got confronted on that by a speaker at a camp one time, not directly, he spoke to the whole group and then we met with him like, yeah, you're right. I either need to stop talking about this or I need to do what I can do about it. And so in our case, we fostered and adopted a couple of kids, which, you know, now I can't imagine my family without them, of course. But, but again, I would say, yeah, and I like passing that along like people who are going to say, oh, we're helpless. We can't change things, but you're not doing the things you could do to change. That's in America. The ultimate form of hypocrisy is complaining about the government and not voting. Right. That is hypocrisy. You're saying you care about this, but you actually don't care about this. And I think that's a totally appropriate, I mean, the Bible calls out hypocrisy kind of constantly and the recognition. So what makes a Christian, hopefully not a hypocrite is that I would say, yeah, I'm jacked up. I messed up and I knew I am. And I try to put these things in alignment, but I fail all the time. And so it's a great word, a vital word. And there are times when it is very appropriate to use it. You just can't assume you know other people's motives. Right. So that's what you have to uncover sometimes first. Okay. Thank you for joining us for this episode of Reconstructed Faith. If you enjoyed what you heard or were challenged, please leave us a review. We'll help other people find us. If you have questions or a topic you'd like to hear discussed, shoot me an email at info at southspring.org. Reconstructed Faith is a resource of South Spring Baptist Church. Remember, don't give up. Trust God. Search for answers. Go to www.reconstructedfaith.org. For more information, visit www.reconstructedfaith.org.

Yes.
So again, a religious conservative is one who's focused on the issues of the past, the
tradition, what is tried and true.
And so we would look at church fathers.
What did the church fathers say?
How did they interpret this?
What does the raw fundamental of the scriptures say?
Sometimes it's even how have we always interpreted this?
And so what's been the same interpretation for a thousand years?
Okay, so that's going to be the- what does everyone agree upon?
What do the church fathers agree upon?
What does the church authority agree on?
What are the found fundamentals?
A liberal, so again, we're talking religious philosophy right now.
If we talk conservative biblical hermeneutics or liberal biblical hermeneutics, you can
totally imagine the more liberal biblical hermeneutic is going to be answering the question,
what does this mean to me?
And the more conservative is going to be, what did this mean from the beginning?
And so the hermeneutic that we taught in this podcast is largely a conservative biblical
hermeneutic, which is what John meant when he wrote a passage matters more than what
I think it means now.
Right.
Now-
And that has nothing to do with-
How I vote.
Right, exactly.
That has nothing to do with it.
That is conservative or liberal, even progressive are just tags.
They're a type of way of type of philosophical engagement.
And so you apply it to political philosophy or religious philosophy or any other area
of philosophy you're going to have in any area, any school of thought, let's say it
that way.
In any school of thought, you will have the more conservative and you will have the more
liberal.
If you've been watching The Chosen, recently they've begun to talk more and more about
the two major schools of rabbis or the two major schools of the Sanhedrin at the time
of Jesus.
Those are, one is the conservative and one is the liberal.
This is not new.
This battle of who is more focused on the traditional and who is more focused on the
liberal on the individual freedoms or even on progressive, meaning change for the sake
of change, is a like, of course that's not new.
Of course that's the Plato thought about it, Socrates thought about it.
I mean, this is not new.
It's an ancient conversation.
And so now if we oversimplify it to only mean like there are conservatives, there are not.
There is no one who is a conservative about every area of philosophy or school of thought.
No one is.
For example, Al Mohler the other day referenced, he's like, I'm not a progressive, but I love
antibiotics and I love airplanes.
And there was a day when the traditional conservative thought was if God meant us to fly, he would
have given us wings.
That would have been the conservative perspective.
And so he's like, so when it comes to a flight, when it comes to air flight, I'm kind of a
progressive.
I want it better.
And medication.
I want it better, faster, more effective.
Let's change it.
Let's tear down the past and make something new.
Like yeah, all of us are conservative in some ways, liberal in some ways, progressive in
some ways.
Of course we are.
And so it's never going to be accurate to label someone and go, you're just, you're
liberal about everything.
I promise you they're not.
Or whatever.
So.
But it makes sense looking at it kind of from the political lens that these perspectives
would be at odds with each other.
Absolutely.
Because their end goal.
The way to reach the end goal is very different.
It's very different.
What is the purpose of government?
What is it supposed to provide?
What's it supposed to accomplish?
So just to make it easy on people to hear, right now in America, if you divide out the
two parties, Republican and Democrat, stereotypically though not universally, Republican Party tends
to be conservative, moving towards liberal, so conservative liberal-ish.
And the Democrats tend to be liberal, progressive-ish.
And so that's kind of where our parties are right now.
And that expresses the disagreement.
The conservative parties or the conservative side of the thing is more likely to say, let's
stick to the original meaning of things.
Let's go back to this.
Let's look to family values, things that have been valued for a long, long time.
And the more liberal, more progressive is going to say, no, we need to be focusing on
personal rights, individual freedoms, and the government protect those.
And that really does decide.
I mean, when you look at our parties and when you see them fight about things, man, they're
pretty close.
It really is kind of how they, what they fight about.
And what we're not saying is that if you are the party of political, the Republicans that
tend to be politically conservative does not mean that they are religiously conservative.
That's right.
No, it's not the same.
That's not interchangeable at all.
That's right.
That's right.
In fact, Christianity is not the most conservative religion by any means.
Right.
Islam is way more conservative a religion, even though it came into existence 600 years
later.
Now, certain forms of Judaism are more conservative.
You're saying you're meaning politically conservative.
Or religious.
Okay.
As a religious, and so again, keep in mind within Christianity, there are more liberal
and more conservative.
Right.
But if you divide, if you connect all the religions, which ones are more conservative
or more liberal, it changes.
It's different too.
So again, it's just, it's the simplif, oversimplification of assigning a title.
Oh, you're conservative.
Yeah.
And what that then is supposed to tell me is I can now predict everything you're going
to say and do.
Yeah.
And it's just not, it's not accurate.
And it's a mistake to link them.
And you can be liberal in one, even within politics, you can have a more liberal perspective
on one political plank, and a more conservative perspective on a different political plank.
And that's allowed.
In fact, I mean, that's in fact, every, I think kind of everyone probably does.
Yeah.
And so kind of switching gears to another term that I think would be valuable for us
to talk about as we're bringing up this idea of kind of having a liberal bent or a conservative
bent is the idea of hypocrisy.
Yeah.
And so we hear that word thrown out a lot, especially in deconstruction, having somebody,
and this is not also, this is not the first time we've talked about hypocrisy.
We've talked about it in previous episodes.
Absolutely.
But I know again in the future.
But how, how do we need to understand this or what is, what is a way that we should be
thinking about hypocrisy when it comes to this topic?
Because hypocrisy is play acting.
That's the literal definition.
That's the literal definition.
That's right.
And so...
It's a Greek word.
Yes.
That references masks.
Yes.
If I remember correctly, I was trying to look it up real quick.
But someone who, and when we see the term hypocrite in the Bible, that's what we're seeing
is someone who is attempting to intentionally delude others or who behaves in one way while
verbalizing something different.
And so it's a natural thing on Christianity because some in Christianity, Christianity
actually offers one of the few solutions to hypocrisy, which we'll get to, but is when
people have grown up being quote, preached at, you know, somebody says, sin, sin, this
is sin, this is sin, this is sin, this is sin, this is sin.
And then it turns out the person is doing those things.
That's a, I had a friend who was an evangelist for teens.
And I remember him standing up in front of a group of parents one time and he was holding
his hands in such a way that he clearly had a martini glass in one hand and a cigarette
in the other hand.
And he's going, kids don't use drugs.
And like that is hypocrisy.
And when you speak, this is what's morally right.
Ignore the fact that I'm using drugs right in front of you, that I'm taking an alcohol
and help me out.
Thank you, nicotine.
And so that's hypocrisy.
When you have a televangelist who creates a political party to get rid of pornography,
and then it turns out later, he's been hiring prostitutes, that's hypocrisy.
Now, why isn't that then the end of Christianity automatically?
Because the main one is because we aren't hypocrites because we claim that we are messed
up sinners.
And so any Christian who claims that we've got it all together, we're morally right,
we're perfect.
Yeah, you are a hypocrite.
Because I guarantee you, you're not.
And you're hiding something or you're not hiding it well.
So here's another thing that I feel like people might interpret as hypocrisy.
And it is, well, this person, they say that they're a Christian, but they vote for Democrats.
So how would, by the way, or the other way around, I've heard the exact, yes, you claim
to be a Christian, but you don't care about.
So here's a great one in today's.
Yeah, exactly.
You're pro-life, but you don't care about homeless kids.
And the kids, once they're born at all.
Right.
Or you say black lives matter, but you should say all lives matter.
Like that's a, well, if black lives matter, then I'd say hypocrisy to say only one ethnic
group.
So both sides sling mud, that's called, about hypocrisy all the time.
Because Christians, we would say, yeah, well, I mean, welcome to humans.
Right?
Yes.
Sometimes.
Are we saying that that, like, is that a correct way of saying, like when we say, well, that's
hypocritical.
Is that actually hypocritical?
It might be.
Okay.
It may be emphasis, like, like with the black lives matter slogan.
I'm not supporting the movement or the website or anything, but the slogan does not say that
all lives don't matter.
It's just saying we're drawing attention to the fact that sometimes it doesn't seem like
black lives matter the way they should.
And so we're not saying that other lives don't matter.
We're just, no, we're just trying to talk about this right now.
The same thing would be true about, you know, if I get up and say, if somebody gets up and
says they're pro-life, you know, we need to protect unborn children.
Well, what about these other kids?
Yeah, absolutely.
Those two, we're just drawing attention right now to, that's not hypocrisy to say we're trying
to care for one population.
That doesn't mean we don't care about the other.
We're just bringing attention to this one.
Oh, you only care about foster kids, not adopted kids.
No, we just don't have, we can't do both.
We can't do everything all the time, right?
So that's not, I don't think that's hypocrisy.
It is hypocrisy though, if you actually don't care about, so if you say, here's one of my
favorites, two populations that call each other hypocrites kind of constantly is people
who are pro-capital punishment, but anti-abortion and vice versa.
And so what is the, how do you deal with, so you believe in the sanctity of human life,
but you also believe the government should be able to take away human life, that seems
hypocritical to some.
Or you say you want to protect children, but you don't want to get rid of guns.
That seems hypocritical because a lot of children die from gun violence.
So what I love is when people who just assume that, oh, you must be a hypocrite because,
but the other side will say the same, you say you want to protect children, but you won't
arm guards at the school.
You're a hypocrite.
There's always two sides to this.
And so sometimes when you can get people together and realize, and the gun control one is one
I've seen happen when you sit down and somebody says, oh, you're trying to protect kids just
like I am.
You just think there's a better way to do it.
So this isn't a matter of you hate kids and I love kids, which would be hypocrisy.
It is, no, no, we both love kids.
We're both trying to take care of them.
We just disagree on the best way to do it.
Well, that's not hypocrisy.
That's just disagreement.
Like the humility to admit where you do agree.
Yeah.
Yeah.
And so anyway, we would hope for that whenever possible, that that's part of the conversation.
And I think it's even more damaging when you associate it with Christianity, when it's
Christians having those conversations of saying, I'm painting hypocrisy on you because you
don't see eye to eye politically on how to handle this situation with me.
It's like you're not serving the Lord because you politically think this is the way to handle
the situation.
Yeah.
Yeah.
There's a an area of hypocrisy that I got called out on that I really appreciate it.
And it changed my life, which was the claim that I wanted to change our nation, turn things
around for our nation, you know, have a Christian great awakening, all this type of thing.
And someone said, well, you realize if we fostered and adopted all the kids out of the
foster and adoption system, we would then probably have the influence over the rest
of our nation.
We could shut down prisons.
We could, you know, we could do make all kinds of massive changes.
And it's not like we don't know how to do that.
This is you don't need to wait and figure out how to do this.
You can do this now.
You can have a role in this.
Well, when I got confronted on that by a speaker at a camp one time, not directly, he spoke
to the whole group and then we met with him like, yeah, you're right.
I either need to stop talking about this or I need to do what I can do about it.
And so in our case, we fostered and adopted a couple of kids, which, you know, now I can't
imagine my family without them, of course.
But, but again, I would say, yeah, and I like passing that along like people who are going
to say, oh, we're helpless.
We can't change things, but you're not doing the things you could do to change.
That's in America.
The ultimate form of hypocrisy is complaining about the government and not voting.
Right.
That is hypocrisy.
You're saying you care about this, but you actually don't care about this.
And I think that's a totally appropriate, I mean, the Bible calls out hypocrisy kind
of constantly and the recognition.
So what makes a Christian, hopefully not a hypocrite is that I would say, yeah, I'm jacked
up.
I messed up and I knew I am.
And I try to put these things in alignment, but I fail all the time.
And so it's a great word, a vital word.
And there are times when it is very appropriate to use it.
You just can't assume you know other people's motives.
Right.
So that's what you have to uncover sometimes first.
Okay.
Thank you for joining us for this episode of Reconstructed Faith.
If you enjoyed what you heard or were challenged, please leave us a review.
We'll help other people find us.
If you have questions or a topic you'd like to hear discussed, shoot me an email at info
at southspring.org.
Reconstructed Faith is a resource of South Spring Baptist Church.
Remember, don't give up.
Trust God.
Search for answers.
